overview: From 2025-09-01 to 2025-10-01, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 239 new PRs (164 merged), 92 new issues, and 112 active contributors.

topIssues.title: op-node/p2p/gossip - ConfigureGossip overwrites sane defaults with zero values
topIssues.author: wood-jp
topIssues.body:
**Bug Description**

https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/develop/op-node/p2p/gossip.go#L146
```
	params := BuildGlobalGossipParams(rollupCfg)

	// override with CLI changes
	params.D = p.MeshD
	params.Dlo = p.MeshDLo
	params.Dhi = p.MeshDHi
	params.Dlazy = p.MeshDLazy
```
This sets the params values directly to those passed in. However, if the passed in struct does not have a value explicitly set (eg `MeshDHi`) then the zero value (0 in this case) is used, which replaced the sane default set earlier with `BuildGlobalGossipParams` (12 btw).

**Steps to Reproduce**
n/a - I've given you the exact code that is wrong.

**Expected behavior**
Should only overwrite these values when non-zero

**Environment Information:**
n/a

**Configurations:**
n/a

**Logs:**
n/a

**Additional context**
n/a

---

⚠️ **Notice:** Issues that do not include the following sections will be subject to closure:
- Bug Description
- Steps to Reproduce
- Environment Information

Please ensure all required sections are filled out accurately to expedite the debugging process and improve issue resolution efficiency.

topIssues.title: op-batcher: Improve throttling intensity metric
topIssues.author: sebastianst
topIssues.body: The intensity metric is always set for all controllers, to the actual value for the active one and to 0 for the inactive ones. It would be nice to only set the value for the active one so it's immediately visible in Grafana which one is active. A case to handle is that the controller type is changed for a running batcher instance, because unfortunately Prometheus metrics don't allow _unsetting_ a value. We could then just set the last controller's value to 0 so that the new one appears. It's not perfect as the old controller type would then continue to have a 0 value metric.

topIssues.title: Implement Websockets support in the Kurtosis Reverse Proxy
topIssues.author: serpixel
topIssues.body:
<!--
Need help?
Refer to our contributing guidelines for additional information about making a good issue:
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently websockets will not be reachable through the Traefik websocket proxy. This means we need to use a direct connection (as seen in #17172). We would want to use the reverse proxy to be consistent with the rest of services.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...]
-->

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I had an initial stab at this, seems that upgrading to traefik v3 and using TCP routing would sort out the issue (but ended up breaking the rest of endpoints).
We're also using an old version of traefik (v2.10) which has a [known websockets issue](https://github.com/dani-garcia/vaultwarden/discussions/3516) so perhaps updating to the last version and doing some routing can also work.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.
-->

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
<!--
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.
-->

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
-->

topIssues.title: L2CL<>L2EL: Find out condition of L2EL for starting EL Syncing
topIssues.author: pcw109550
topIssues.body:
Find out the condition of EL that EL is able to EL Sync. This may differ by node implementations/networks and first priority is op-geth with op-sepolia.

We need this because when we do multiple EL Sync, we need to make the EL be able to EL Sync again.

Some artifacts(not confirmed):
> op-geth must not have finalized block to trigger EL Sync(snap sync).

Necessary for removal of ReqRes Sync to EL Sync. Must understand the starting conditions of EL Sync to rely on it.

topIssues.title: op-sync-tester,op-acceptance-tests: sync test using the sync-tester
topIssues.author: pcw109550
topIssues.body:
Add sync acceptance tests using the sync tester.

---

sysgo → easier to config because while we are booting the system, we may make a preset to enable/disable space.

@pcw109550 's suggestion is that, to make a minimal feedback loop to test, lets do in sysgo with activation of isthmus.

- [x] sysgo → simple

1. Spawn EL, CLA with isthmus enabled
2. Spawn Sync tester
3. Connect the CLB with the Sync tester
4. And make sure the CLB connected with the Sync Tester advances(syncs)

CLB ↔ Sync-Tester ↔ EL ↔ CLA 

- [ ] sysgo(extension to sysext can be done in follow up work)  → real data(op-mainnet etc)

1. hardcode the public endpoint (or OP Labs internal EL endpoint) to the test and give this to the initialization of the sync tester.
2. we may spawn CL to test
3. Make CL to sync until isthmus(or hf block - 1)
4. Check CL correctly advances after new hardfork

---

Test case Ideas(ordered by priority)

- [ ] Check every OP Stack HF transitions, not only Isthmus, but all HFs for real data.
- [ ] Multiple CLs, Single Sync Tester: Each CLs will initialize their own mock EL endpoints given by the sync tester. This validates that multiple CLs can sync together.
- [ ] User Tx with Sync Tester: Current tests only sync blocks which only contain deposit tx. Create user tx inside L2 blocks and check the L2CLs are synced also.

topPRs.title: feat: introduce fee splitter for revenue share
topPRs.author: 0xDiscotech
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Introduce the `FeeSplitter` predeploy as part of a new revenue-sharing feature. The goal is to make revenue sharing simpler and more modular, with configurable values and automated handling where possible.

Includes supporting contracts like `SuperchainRevSharesCalculator`, `L1Withdrawer`, and `FeesDepositor`, which act as periphery components of the system and cover the first expected use case.

This is opt-in, but will be enabled by default on fresh chains at genesis. Operators must set a chain fees recipient address on L2 for splits to work.

`FeeVaults` were updated to be more flexible with setters, while keeping backwards compatibility.

**Tests**

* All new contracts are fully unit tested.
* Genesis logic has dedicated tests, and there ar integration tests covering the full main flow.
* Invariant tests added using Foundry as fuzzer.

**Additional context**

* [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/782)
* [design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/328)

**Metadata**

When the `FeesDepositor` contract for OP’s L1 fees is deployed, it should be linked [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17505)

⚠️  **Disclaimer**: We made minimal changes to the Go files to get the checks passing and did so carefully. Go isn’t our primary expertise, so we’d appreciate extra attention from Go reviewers on these edits.

topPRs.title: feat(governance): proposal validator
topPRs.author: 0xOneTony
topPRs.body:
**Description**

This PR introduces the `ProposalValidator` contract  designed to enable permissionless proposals in the Optimism
governance system, as detailed in the [design doc](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/260) and [technical spec](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/701).

topPRs.title: feat: dev feature flagging in OPCM
topPRs.author: smartcontracts
topPRs.body: Adds functionality to tests and OPCM that makes it possible to execute use feature flags in the OPCM that selectively utilize specific functionality. This flag is represented as a 32 byte bitmap for op-deployer compatibility and makes it possible to support 32 unique development features at the same time.

This will help prevent unexpected behavior within op-deployer that could

topContributors.summary: geoknee: Focused on the "min-base-fee" feature, proposing changes to both implementation and design documentation. This work included opening a pull request to bring in op-geth code in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17307) and another to update a calculation in the feature's design doc (#333). Alongside this development, they actively supported the team by providing 12 code reviews. Their commits primarily consisted of bug fixes and tests, spread across 47 modified files.

scharissis: Focused on improving infrastructure and the acceptance testing framework, landing a significant logging refactor in `ethereum-optimism/infra#453` and introducing `mise` for tool version management via `ethereum-optimism/infra#452`. They drove further testing improvements by creating and closing two issues (`infra#398`, `optimism#16272`) to streamline test execution and provided 7 code reviews. With ongoing work in `op-acceptance-tests` and `kurtosis-devnet`, their contributions were primarily centered on bug fixes and feature enhancements.

blmalone: Focused on improving CI performance and stability within the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository. They delivered a notable performance improvement by optimizing account access decoding in CI (#1178) and reduced common CI failures by adjusting concurrent processes (#1177). Their work, primarily consisting of bug fixes, also included smaller corrections to versioning and nonce handling (#1183, #1176), with changes concentrated in documentation and configuration files.

smartcontracts: This month, smartcontracts focused on a significant body of work centered on bug fixes and new features, authoring 31 commits. This effort resulted in substantial changes across 167 files (+4676/-1739 lines), with a primary focus on bugfix work (68%). While no pull requests were merged, they participated in code review by providing comments on 4 pull requests.

JosepBove: Focused on the `superchain-ops` repository, preparing a significant change to enable and disable LivenessModule2 templates. This work is captured in an open pull request (#1179) which modifies 130 files with over 5,000 lines of code changes. Alongside this development effort, they also participated in code review by providing comments on 6 pull requests. Based on the file modifications, this work had a strong emphasis on testing.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on improving the project's build process, opening a pull request to enhance the build recipe for op-deployer (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17304). In addition to this work, they contributed collaboratively by reviewing and approving one pull request and commenting on an issue. Their code changes were entirely focused on this tooling enhancement.

pcw109550: This month, pcw109550 focused on improving the testing capabilities within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. Their main contribution was adding sync namespace support to the `op-sync-tester` via PR #17299.
